Fields.DialogueText: Be ready. They're almost in range.
@BATTLE
Now, exhale.
*phew*
Right. Congratulations - I'm ninety percent sure you still have at least one working lung.

Fields.MenuText: Glad to hear it.
And the ten percent possibility?
Y'know, Doctor van Geffen actually gives me useful feedback.

Fields.DialogueText: It's to distract you from her evil ways. Don't fall for it.
This is all a terrible dream and I'm about to wake up in a palatial hotel suite.
You know me. I always aim to please.
On that note...
Any chance you got two decent nights' sleep in a row? You look marginally less haggard than usual.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, actually. This may be the best I've felt in months.
That's a lie and you know it.
I'm not about to collapse, Doctor. That's really all I ask.

Fields.DialogueText: Heh.
Seriously, I know it's too soon to relax, but... there's an absolutely vital conference going on in Zurich, and it isn't my problem. There's nothing I can do about it right now.
Glad to hear you're reaching for the stars.
No, I'm okay.
For the first time in weeks, I have a few seconds to think about something other than international diplomacy. I'm not going to lie - I could get used to it.
And that's... good?
Yeah. That'll come back to bite you.
Stalking the Belle. Ssh.
You know she can hear you.
Seaman Kirishima? What're you up to?
Hai. It's lulling her into a false sense of security.
*sigh*
Leave her be, Seaman. She's got a lot on her plate.
Exactly! And I can't figure out what it is!
Well, for one thing, she's working out competency tests.
We've picked up a lot of crew members who don't have anything like the training they should. It's past time we identify weaknesses and start working on them.
Why are you looking at me like that?
Tell me this means you're going to make Augie study how ranks actually work.
Among other things.
THIS IS GOING TO BE HILARIOUS.

Fields.MenuText: Yes.
Uh-huh. I like how you think that Mr. Cassel is the one who has big problems with military protocol.
I will neither confirm nor deny.

Fields.DialogueText: Ryōkai!
It's okay. You don't have to.
But... that's not the main thing she's up to. Is it?
And why do you say that?
I mean, she's checking to make sure everything's fastened down, like we're expecting bad weather - but look at that sky.
And the inventory reviews. And Augie said that there was a full, unscheduled maintenance kerfluffle with the radio room. And-

Fields.MenuText: You can stop there.
We really don't give you enough work to do, do we?
When you need to know about it, you'll know.

Fields.DialogueText: I could keep going, though.
Please don't.
... Isn't there another conclusion we could be drawing here?
Aww!
Seriously, I just-
*ALARM*
Right. Stay safe, Kanchou!
@BATTLE
Case in point. Work on that salute.
Well, this is... snug.
Mm. Reminds me of life back in Moscow. Fourteen of us lived in a one-bedroom-
That's funny. I thought you lived on the street. I mean, when you didn't have a dacha with hot and cold running-
I don't remember your stories. You should really do me the courtesy of forgetting mine.
Okay, quiet down - and thank you all for coming. I know this is irregular, but I value all of your opinions. Even Lugin's.
Does this mean I can smoke?
No. It's terrible for you.
Everything out here is terrible for you, Doctor. We might as well let them pick and choose.
I repeat - quiet down.
Sorry.
Points of order. One. The Zurich Conference is... there's been a complication.
The Secretary General of the League of Nations, Joseph Avenol, has been hospitalized. I don't know the story, and I don't know how bad it is, but my sources say that foul play is suspected.
Excellent. The man's a-
Let's not editorialize.
I suppose I'm here to be the one to ask, "Is this our problem?" So, is this our problem?
In the sense that we're involved in the investigation? No.
Beyond that - well, my sense of Monsieur Avenol is that he's made it his priority to make the League of Nations as welcoming as possible to Germany and Japan, to lure them back into the fold.
Or else he's just another bigot and thug and he supports their agendas in general.
Hey. The Captain wants quiet.
Ja. Sorry.
I think you mean "Sorry, sir."
Ja. That. Sir.
It's fine. What matters most, with the League, is what happens next. The Dutch and the Belgians have proposed a reasonably workable Neutrality Fleet for a common defense against the Morganas.
The fleet would be coordinated by the League, though, and would consist of League members, or at least League "associates." Whatever that ends up meaning.
And an assassination attempt on the Secretary General might kill it all before it starts. I just don't know.
But that *is* our problem. If this all falls apart, it could set the Morgana war effort back too far to recover from.
That brings me to point two. We've had a couple of nice days off-
Is that really-
Yes, I know, we've had battles. But I think we all know we've gone through worse.
And we're about to go through worse again?
We're about to conduct an experiment.
We know that Captain Ferneck and the Admiral Scheer bounced from one side of the Atlantic to the other in a matter of seconds.
Those of us who've been here since September 1 know we've had similar experiences. For all we know, we've had several.
What we want to do is see if we can make it happen on command.

Fields.MenuText: I don't think it's possible to overstate the value of a fleet that can be wherever it needs to be within a matter of days.
It should make some of the right people sweat.
We want the world's governments to be looking at a shiny toy and not trying to knife each other in the back.

Fields.DialogueText: Ooh!
Yes?
Do we actually know how to do that, though?
Pardon me. Is this serious? Teleportation?
Probably not serious. Could be real, though.
Even the most down-to-earth Belles get fuzzy when they try to talk about this. "The shortest distance between two points on a page is when you fold the page so they touch."
That's all we have to go on. It's all metaphor, and I don't think they understand it a whole lot better than I do.
The simplest version of the story is that, back in September, a bunch of doors opened, and Morganas came through from somewhere else.
Morganas may have the keys to those doors - but sometimes a Belle can force them open, step through to... somewhere else, and then step back out into the real world.
Well. That's absolutely terrifying.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah.
Try not to think about it.
If it makes you feel any better, I'm told that that other place is probably not literally Hell.

Fields.DialogueText: ...Bah. This calls for a cigarette, whether or not the doctors approve.
Do we... I mean, does our friendly Belle have any control over where we come out?
Hopefully, yes. I'm told my help will be required as well, but I don't know much more than that.
Interesting. I'll just be swimming to port now.
This is *amazing*. Do we have a working movie camera? We should film this!
You are a very strange girl.
Point three. Assuming we all survive the next couple of days, some of you from non-military, non-nautical backgrounds can expect to-
*ALARM*
I guess it can wait.
@BATTLE
Morganas approaching, Captain.
I see them.
And we really think that being in the mist is necessary for the... jump?
It's consistent with our past experiences and with the contents of Captain Ferneck's debrief. But, honestly, it's just a gamble.
Not like we weren't going to plow in and fight the Morganas anyway.
Exactly.
So. Should I ask how your officer training program is going?
It's fine. Lord knows I have my flaws, but nobody ever accused me of not being willing to do my homework, Captain.
Turns out I'm not the only one who felt like he was learning to swim in the middle of a whirlpool. It's reassuring, is what I mean.
You were first officer on the Lune, right?
Sure. But, I don't know if you noticed, sir, but this is a slightly different experience.

Fields.MenuText: Point.
It's all just keeping your ship from sinking and keeping to schedules, Lieutenant.
Well, for what it's worth, none of us trained for most of this nonsense.

Fields.DialogueText: You know, Captain, I don't think anybody ever told me what you were doing ten minutes before your battlefield promotion. Were you already some kind of officer? If you don't mind me asking.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah. Not to sound conceited, but I was always pretty likely to end up with a command.
Are you kidding? There's a mop out there with my fingerprints ground into the handle.
Ask the Doctor that question. He could use the laugh.

Fields.DialogueText: Probably not the easiest way to do it, though.
No. And the former Captain deserved better than to have his career end the way it did.
So... before you were Captain, you were the ship's answer to Sayako?
Let's not go there, Lieutenant.
Yeah. Probably for the best.
Noted.
*ALARM*
It seems our favorite Belle thinks we should be paying attention to the enemy now.
@BATTLE
Ah. You're awake?
Seems that way. You're... not the doctor I expect to find hovering over me in my private quarters. No offense.
Huh.
I take it I was carried here from the bridge?
You walked most of the way. How much do you remember?
Before you answer, drink.
Medicinal?
Water. You need the hydration.
Agreed.
...Oh, I needed that. Well, where to start...
After the battle we cleared the bridge, except for me and the lady of the ship. We were going to try to make a jump from the Celtic Sea to the south of the Bay of Biscay.
The Spanish would confirm instantaneous travel, and... whatever. Obviously something went wrong.
Things just got... strange. She was in a trance for hours - maybe a day or more - and I couldn't open the door to leave the bridge.
I don't know how long it was. I tried to sleep a couple of times. Eventually I spotted a light outside the ship and was able to talk her into aiming the ship toward it.
The two of you were alone on the bridge for just under nineteen minutes.
No.
Yes.
No. The rest of the ship may have been knocked unconscious, or maybe the clocks stopped, but I promise you, I paid a lot of attention to my watch until it stopped working.
*I* promise *you*, we would have seen many more contusions and fractures if the entire crew had collapsed at the same moment.
There were... unusual phenomena, yes. Whether they were mass hallucinations or atmospheric irregularities I still can't say, but-
We should have gotten Sayako that movie camera.
Well, that might have been asking for trouble.
Right. So what did you see?
Lights. Shadows. I don't know. But it lasted no more than thirteen minutes - the clocks didn't stop.
Right. Any medical aftereffects?
Nothing so far - apart from you sleeping like the dead for six hours.
I had to chase the Belle out of here with a broom, incidentally. She's very attached to you.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you.
That... really wasn't necessary.
Hell. I'd better talk to her. She's probably plotting revenge somewhere.

Fields.DialogueText: It was good exercise.
Oh, I think it was. That one needs more people willing to say no, I think.
*shrugs*
This reminds me, we need to start taking steps to reduce the risk of pregnancy among the female crew members.

Fields.MenuText: Agreed. But let's not have this conversation now.
Oh, I promise you, we're updating fraternization rules.
Wait, why does this remind you of that?

Fields.DialogueText: As you wish.
Excellent. But we also need prophylactics.
Must I spell out everything for you?
Later.
Never mind.
Right. I don't suppose we made it to the north coast of Spain?
We did not.
We are just outside of Boston Harbor, near the United States.
What?
I'm told it's a "safe zone." Whatever that means.
I need to get to the bridge.
The USS Constitution.
I don't know what that means either.
The oldest surviving warship in the world with a woken Belle. Reports say the Morganas seem to be afraid of her.
Thank you for the report, Lieutenant.
Now, off the record. When you tell me you gave her permission to go, are you being truthful or are you trying to keep me from throwing her in the brig for a year?
No, it's true. I managed to catch her as she was trying to slip off the ship - and after she spent twenty minutes rhapsodizing about diagonal riders and the sinking of the Guerriere I just gave up.
I figured she wasn't going to embarrass us, basically. But don't tell her I said so.
My lips are sealed.
Kanchou! Are you feeling better? Isn't this amazing? We should have filmed everything! But I don't care, because I got to meet Constitution, and she's amazingly amazing! Amazing squared!
We think they gave her sugar.
That's enough out of you, Grumpy-kun.
Hey. We'd moved on from "Grumpy-kun."
That's enough of that. Seaman, I think the Captain's waiting for a report.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you, Lieutenant.
Take a breath first, Seaman.
For the record, I wouldn't have minded a few more seconds of Mr. Cassel being tortured.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you for that, Captain. Thank you so, so much.
Maybe you should salute, too. Have you been reading the rules?
Okay. Now I've had enough.
Hai, Kanchou!
Right.
So, Constitution gave me a lot of papers for you to read. Since she woke up, she's- I mean, her keel was laid down almost exactly 145 years ago, so she's not out shooting at battleships, right?
But she's been banging the drum to the President and to Congress - mostly Congress - non-stop. She says she writes twenty or thirty letters a day arguing for a joint effort against the Morganas.
And she thinks the President, at least, agrees with her. About joining the League, about us being the world's best hope-
She didn't say that.
It was implied!
You relapsed!
I'd say I'm sorry to interrupt, but I'm really not - did she have anything to say about how she's keeping the Morganas out of Boston? I've read reports, but-
But nobody can explain why they seem to be afraid of a complement of 32-pounders?
What are 32-pounders?
Old guns.
You really need to do the reading.
Anyway, I think it has something to do with how she saved us.
Explain.
Well, she said that she thought we were "drifting away," so she kind of... reached out and gave us a hand to get to Boston.
And maybe that means she can interfere with Morgana tricks too? Maybe? She's even more vague about that kind of thing than our Belle, to be honest.
But she thinks she can help us find our way back. Generally. She's got this hand-made globe, and she had me point to where we came from, and... well, hopefully we'll be within a few hundred miles.
Did you have the sense that if you pointed somewhere else, she'd be able to help us get there?
So, a two-stop system?  Go from point A to Boston Harbor, then from Boston Harbor to point B?
Maybe. Faster than sailing weeks at a time.
Well, she's probably not going to stay in Boston Harbor, though. She thinks they're going to move her to Norfolk. You know Morgana propaganda broadcasts are becoming more and more of a thing?
And they've been particularly targeting DC.
Right. So if they can park Constitution at or near the Chesapeake, maybe the congressmen can listen to "Don Winslow of the Navy" without having Sedition cut in.
Is Don Winslow an admiral?
I have no idea.
Okay. For now, let's just get back to where we were. Lieutenant, I want us ready to go within the hour.
Are you sure? I mean, I don't want to speak out of turn, Captain, but you haven't had a lot of time to recover from the last trip.

Fields.MenuText: You're speaking out of turn, Mr. Cassel.
I was tired. I hadn't had a stroke. But thank you.
I need to be sure word of our travels reaches Zurich before the conference ends.

Fields.DialogueText: Sorry. Kapitan.
Psst. Salute.
That's enough, Seaman.
Okay. Good.
... Understood. Kapitan.
Oh, and Seaman Kirishima?
Hai?

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you had a good time.
We're bringing on a photographer for these trips.

Fields.DialogueText: You were right. They should be documented.
Oh. Thank you for saying so, Kanchou!
So am I!
She was so nice - and she said she'd write. And, Lieutenant... hang on.
Wait, there's one more thing. Lieutenant... hang on.
Lieutenant, she had a letter for you too. Here.
For me? Specifically?
It's not long. But she wanted to thank you for your service.
... Tell me you didn't read it.
Just over her shoulder. As an appreciative audience!
I'll be reporting to my post now.
Is it done? We've made the jump?
Okay, get the bridge crew back, and let's see if we can figure out where we-
*ALARM*
Oh, come on!
@BATTLE
Sir? You can probably tell just by looking, but I have confirmation - that's Brest out there. We're back in European waters.

Fields.MenuText: Amazing.
Good enough.
Did you happen to get the time?

Fields.DialogueText: Ja.
You're not easy to impress.
We're matching timetables now, but I'd say there couldn't have been more than half an hour between when we lost sight of Boston Harbor and when the Morganas started shooting at us.
Right. We need to make for port.
Lieutenant, let me know if there are any complications. I need to write a thank you letter for the earliest post.
The news from the conference could be a whole lot worse. Avenol's got a pair of broken legs and a number of other injuries, but he's going to survive.
Is he staying on the job?
Sorry - one second. Lugin, take a look and see what's in those crates! We haven't had a chance to inventory yet!
Have we already paid for it all? Whatever it is?
They're donations from Mrs. Granville. Or at least she organized them.
Then there's a chance of alcohol. I'll go take a look!
As for Avenol - no. He's tendered his resignation. His recovery's likely to take a while, and he's not a young man.
Good thing or bad thing?
Depends on who replaces him. Apparently Ribbendorf is hinting that Germany could be coaxed back under the right leadership - but the Dutch are floating an Irish compromise candidate.
This crate seems to be full of... feminine hygiene products. I know a port in the Black Sea where I could sell them for-
No.
No one appreciates genius in his own time.
And our little visit to the States? Has that become public knowledge in diplomatic circles?
I don't think they quite believe it yet, but the cables are coming in from various American embassies. I want to try making another jump - to the Pacific this time.
Boston, then the Pacific.
Correct.
The Pacific Ocean's a big place.
True. I'm aiming for the South China Sea, near Hainan. Morgana activity there has apparently spiked in the last few weeks.
... I'm not thrilled about bolstering the Japanese imperial project to prove an international fleet can be useful, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: If we're smart, it should help the Chinese nationalists at least as much as the Japanese.
I get it. But I hope you agree that the Japanese Navy joining the Neutrality Fleet is kind of a necessity.
Noted.

Fields.DialogueText: Medical supplies here! Enough bandages to wrap this entire ship!
Excellent.
These I could sell for-
No.
Could we at least trade them for-
Well, if you want to go to Boston, we should be able to head out as soon as-
*ALARM*
You had to know that was coming.
I really did.
I'll look at the last of the crates later.
Do that. We'll-
What do I do with the chloroform-doused girl in the steamer trunk, though?
... Excuse me?
@BATTLE
No shortage of those these days.
Keep that grinder cranking, I suppose.
Wow, Kanchou. You look...

Fields.MenuText: I know.
Exhausted?
Even more glamorous than usual?

Fields.DialogueText: Hai. Sure! That's totally what I was going to say!
It definitely wasn't going to be "drooping like a soggy piece of bread."
That's not as dramatic as the word I was leaning towards, but I guess it works.
So was this another one of those trips where it took twenty minutes for everyone on the deck and days for you and Kami-sama on the bridge?
I don't know. Maybe.
Boston still looks beautiful, huh?
Hai. Not getting poisoned and bombed for two straight months is a good look. Who knew?
They're going to miss Constitution when she's gone.
I know. She was hoping to get FDR and the Congress to move up here instead.
I think she's given up on that. They sent a messenger with a hand-written invitation to join the escort detail when she heads south.
I think I told you, she writes a lot of letters.
Mm. The 18th-century handwriting is really impressive, actually.
Kanchou... do you mind if I ask how Marie-France is doing?
I haven't talked to her yet. She seems to be settling in nicely in the brig, though. The guards love her.
Does she have to be there?
She did beat up the Doctor.
Yeah, but that's kind of our fault. If we'd had Doctor van Geffen look at her, they would have just punched it out and everything would've been fine.
I'll try to remember that for future kidnapping victims.
What can you tell me about her? Fanny told me back in September she'd be trying to get our old XO's daughter to join us, but... well, drugged and tied up was not what I was led to expect.
I don't know her. Bertie hadn't been married to her mother or anything. It was just one of those stupid, complicated things. I think her mom had been a dancer somewhere?
I don't know. Bertie sent them money, but it sounded like the times he met her in person didn't go really well.
Do you know what you're going to do with her?
She's not a prisoner, but I don't think we can just dump a French national in Boston with no money and sail away. I'll talk to her after we make the next jump.
Yeah, I mean, I guess as long as we don't all die in the South China Sea, there's no harm done.

Fields.MenuText: That's the spirit!
Has anyone ever told you to think about the words that are going to come out of your mouth before you say them?
Tell that to her lawyers.

Fields.DialogueText: What would be the point of that? I'd just say crazy things more slowly and everyone would get frustrated.
I think I'd rather not.
I'm so glad I have a commanding officer who gets me!
And if you tell me a hundred thousand times that you were being sarcastic I will refuse to accept it every time.
Okay. Fair enough.
Anyway, you'd better be getting on with your duties. We'll be making the next jump sooner rather than later.
Haaaaiiiiiiiii.
Did it work?
The jump? I think so. We're definitely somewhere else, Captain. And it's a lot hotter outside than it is on the bridge.
It really could be the South China Sea, then. We need to-
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Never mind. We have a new priority.
Right. Good job, people - now get the fires out, and somebody find out where we are.
Captain? That city over there is apparently Manila. I don't know the geography of the Philippines very well, but...
Basically, we're on the east side of the South China Sea. We overshot Hainan, but it's not as bad as it could've been.
Do we have any charts?
We should. I've had Lugin building a collection for us in his spare time.
Right. I've seen Lugin's organizational system. Can we *find* the charts?

Fields.MenuText: One thing at a time.
Right. Let's get this sorted now - Mr. Cassel, get word to our friends in Manila that we have a job opening for a trained archivist.

Fields.DialogueText: An archivist? No offense, Kapitan, but--
I'm dead serious. I think we're going to be collecting material from all over the world - better to have it organized from the outset than have to build a system when we're already overwhelmed.
We deal with damage and injuries first. If we can't find local charts in our collection, I'm sure we can get them in Manila.
Anyway, I don't intend to stay here long. The Americans and the Japanese will know that we've appeared on opposite sides of the planet in a week - that's a big success right there.
That said-
Hopefully.
I mean, there may be countries out there who look at globe-trotting fleets and say they're an argument against a unified League fleet. If the US Navy can hop from Pearl to Galveston in an hour....
One problem at a time, Lieutenant. Or however many problems we've got. Thirty?
Minimum.
... At least we get to see Manila.
Mademoiselle Savary? I'm sorry we haven't had much chance to talk before now. I'm-
You're the Capitaine. Je sais. Your face has been in all the newspapers for weeks.
I should thank you for the hospitality. You're the most genial jailors I've ever had the privilege of having.

Fields.MenuText: Have you spent a lot of time in prison, then?
You're welcome. We hope you'll tell your friends about us.
This isn't a jail and you're not a prisoner.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah! You'll forgive the misunderstanding, given the time I spent involuntarily in a tiny locked room after I was delivered here against my will.
Très drôle.
Now, *that* is not the question of a polite host.
It's my understanding that you attacked our doctor upon waking - which, granted, might be understandable under the circumstances - and then attacked him again after he had introduced himself.
That's not behavior we can afford to encourage.
D'accord. I promise not to do it again without provocation.
Right. Listen, at the risk of being blunt, why are you here?
Because an unpleasant Belgian woman wanted me to be.
Okay. Let me rephrase: why did your stepmother think that-
I'd be grateful if you didn't call her that. "Madame Verbiest" will do, don't you think?
Technically it's "Madame Grenville." She did marry your father before he passed away.
I have nobody's word on that but hers and yours. I don't know you.

Fields.MenuText: Fair enough. But I know I'm not lying, and I'm not going to pretend otherwise.
If this is about a contested inheritance, let me just say that I don't care.
Okay. Why did the woman in question knock you out and ship you to me in a trunk?

Fields.DialogueText: Non. I have no reason to believe Monsieur Granville was ever going to leave me anything. I certainly didn't want him to.
Well... we'll leave that for now.
As for why she sent me-
Maybe she thought we should talk about Eufrasio Pansera.
Anything's possible - but since I don't know who that is, I think it's unlikely.
He's one of the men I believe she hired to assault Joseph Avenol.

Fields.MenuText: ... Okay, I wasn't expecting that.
Interesting. Do you have any proof?
And you think she'd tell me if she did? Ha!

Fields.DialogueText: Well, when I asked her about it, she had me knocked out and dumped on a ship bound for the far corners of the globe.

Fields.MenuText: Okay, fair point.
Maybe she just doesn't like you.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine, again, all that I know about you is that you came from nowhere to command a single ship that has turned into a fleet.
I know that Madame Verbiest is working behind the scenes to give you influence, if not command, over the single greatest naval power our world has ever seen.
And I know that you, in turn, declared her married to my late father - who died on your ship - and that that eased her way toward inheriting a considerable fortune.
Oh. And I should say I'm a journalist.
*ALARM*
You should probably take that as a sign that sometimes a coincidence is just a coincidence.
This is... are we under attack?
We are. Get back to your quarters - we'll resume this conversation under quieter circumstances. Or we'll be dead and it won't matter.
I... d'accord. Bonne chance.
Oh - and happy Armistice Day.
Huh. So it is.
@BATTLE
The Port of Brest says hello, Captain - and they warn that there are Morganas in the vicinity.
Right. We'll sniff them out. Any word on the conference?
I'll ask.
So, we made it back in one piece again.
Except we were aiming for Rotterdam.
And you look wrecked again. How much time passed on the bridge during the last jump?
I don't know. Probably less than a day. It's still miraculous, however you cut it.
As long as it keeps working.

Fields.MenuText: Let's try to be positive, Lieutenant.
I have to believe it's already helped the pro-League argument at the conference. Whatever happens next, it's a win.
If it stops working, we'll find something else. I'm not getting complacent here.

Fields.DialogueText: Right. So, changing the subject...
Go ahead.
Blondie. I know she says she's a reporter, but I don't know her name from Le Temps - or from the Paris radio, for that matter.
She's young, and you haven't lived in Paris for a while.
True. But she's a young woman - and, to state the obvious, she's pretty. If she had a really influential journalism gig in the first place, I think she'd be moderately famous.
She's not claiming to be Louise Faure-Favier. I'm assuming she's freelance - and probably hungry.
I'm more interested in her allegations.
That Fanny arranged to have Avenol pushed down a flight of stairs? I don't know - if Fanny was a criminal mastermind trying to cover up her sins, she'd have better ways to get rid of the girl-
Marie-France.
She'd have better ways to get rid of Marie-France than to have her ship off with us. I think it's probably just rich people family drama.
You don't agree?
I think it can be both family drama and something else.
Whatever strings Fanny pulled to get this conference going... it's not like she's an aristocrat, and it's not like she had a long career in government. There was always something shady about it.
Okay. And, to paraphrase Doc van Gessen, is that our problem?
I just want to find a way to be prepared if it blows up in our faces.
Okay. Let's step back. What would Fanny gain from sidelining Avenol? The man's as pro-German and Italian as any high-profile Frenchman is likely to be, and getting the Germans on board is a priority.
I'd think knocking him out of the picture makes the conference's work harder. That was what you seemed to be assuming.
I'm still assuming that. But-
*ALARM*
Speaking of blowing up in our faces...
@BATTLE
Mademoiselle Savary?
Ah! Bonjour, Capitaine!
Not that you're not welcome at the port, but I would've thought you'd be on your way home by now.
Or at least changed out of the loaner uniform.
Oui! I was going to be! But then Orestes here-
Orest.
Non! That's a stupid name! Embrace the ancient Greek roots! O-REST-EES!
That's not so stupid. *Napoleon,* that's a stupid name.
Anyway, we've been drinking.

Fields.MenuText: I see that.
Right. Well, what Lugin does on his shore leave is his business.
Congratulations.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. You are very observant. I see that about you.
That's the nicest thing anyone's ever said about me.
I... yeah, okay.
Merci!
Spasibo!
So. It seems that you and the Belgian have won the day.
Has there been news?
Officially? Non. The conference will amble along for the rest of the week. But there have been leaks.
Joint naval operations until at least the first day of February. Committees to codify a "neutrality fleet" composed of League members and League associates.
I assume that means the Americans. Everyone knows we need the Americans now, even if they think they're too good for the League.
Nyet. Be fair. The League has a French motto on the seal. You don't do that unless you're planning to irritate the rest of the world.
I have never been fair a day in my life and I do not intend to start now.
That I believe.
And it isn't a French motto. Is it? It's just the name. "Société des Nations." It sounds better in French, anyway.
I'll leave you both to it. Thank you for the news, though. It's... well, it's very welcome.
Capitaine?
Yes?
Were we really in the Philippines? And Boston? I thought that that might be part of the joke - that you and Verbiest would use me as a witness to some great lie.
But it seemed like those places were real. It really did.
Boston isn't real. It's fake buildings the Americans put up to look pretty. Everything behind them is tenements and starvation. Ask McPhee!
But we *were* really there.

Fields.MenuText: Exactly. Sort of.
Yes. We were.
No offense, but if we were going to enact an elaborate fraud, we'd target someone with more influence.

Fields.DialogueText: Offense is absolutely taken... but I think I believe you.
What a strange, strange world.
You know, if we're going to waste the Kapitan's time, we should offer some terrible, cheap wine.
We finished the wine. In fact, we finished the terrible wine, and the cheap wine, and then the wine which was both terrible and cheap.
Da. So you should buy some more.
You're the one with a regular paycheck!
You have seen no conclusive evidence of that, and I strongly resent the insinuation!

Fields.MenuText: Pass. Thank you, though.
If this is a ploy to get me to buy the wine, it's an abject failure.
I could flip a coin for you.

Fields.DialogueText: I think that-
*ALARM*
BWAH! Make it stop!
If you sign on, you'll get used to it. Happens all the time.
@BATTLE
Almost in range, Captain.
All right, people. This is not a drill! Stations, now!
@BATTLE
You'd think they would stop coming.
I'm just glad they haven't made another stab at a blockade. That was a week I'm not in a hurry to repeat.
That was... what, a month ago? Less?
It all flows together, doesn't it?
It does.
But it's a different world, all the same. Just not having to worry about our navies shooting at each other and letting the Morganas pick up the pieces....
We're sure it wasn't a German ship that sank HMS Blanche?
The final word is that it was a Morgana mine.
Whether it's true or not? Sir?

Fields.MenuText: Let's assume it is.
"Sir?" We'll make a sailor out of you yet, Mr. Cassel.
If you have time to be cynical, you have time to study.

Fields.DialogueText: The Nazis just bombed the Shetlands, though. And they certainly haven't stopped abusing Poland's Jews - you heard about the Ezras Israel Synagogue?
I did. But if Germany's talking about "a phased association" with the League for naval defense, then the League is going to have more leverage on human rights.
That's the look you give me when you think I'm being hopelessly naive and you don't know if you can get away with saying it.

Fields.MenuText: You should know that sometimes being in charge means you have to argue the optimistic scenario, whatever you really feel.
We can revisit the topic in six months and see if you're right.
You should absolutely assume you can't get away with saying it.

Fields.DialogueText: Let's not get crazy here, Captain.
Et tu, Lieutenant? You're supposed to be tutoring me!
Yeah, well - you get what you pay for, Mr. Cassel.
He can pack in a lot more cynicism in an hour than studying, Captain.
Here's hoping.
Jawohl.
So. Are you two about ready for your proficiency tests?
Ugh.
You heard the lady of the ship told the docs she'll have tests for them too?
... I assume that went well.
The one with the lower scores is going to have to serve the one with the higher scores breakfast in bunk for a month.
No, I heard the stakes have been upped. Loser has to get a tattoo or something.
They'll just be dueling on the deck inside a week.
... Could be good for morale.
Merci, Capitaine. I do appreciate you taking the time to talk with me.
Though you wish I could have been more forthcoming about operational secrets.
Oh, did I mention that?
Once or twice.
More like thirty or forty times, I know. And I don't apologize!

Fields.MenuText: I get it. It's your job.
You could apologize insincerely. I'd pretend to fall for it. It could be fun.
Yeah, I didn't think you would.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Someone needs to show you a few less complicated ways to have fun, Capitaine.
If you don't mind me saying - you asked a lot of questions about the Zurich Conference, and a number of questions about our mutual Belgian acquaintance....
Oui?
You never asked about Commander Granville.
Is there anything you'd like to know? Off the record?
I'm not sure. Is there anything you think I should know that I don't know, or are you just trying to get a reaction out of me?
Neither. Just making the offer.
... Pardonnez-moi. It was kind of you.
But I can honestly say that the most time I spent with my father since I was a very small child was when I was nineteen years old and he appeared from nowhere to bribe my fiancé into leaving me.
I won't say I didn't love him, but I don't think either one of us would enjoy a conversation about him either. Not right now.

Fields.MenuText: I understand.
I'm sorry to hear it.
I take it your fiancé took the bribe?

Fields.DialogueText: C'est la vie. What happens, happens.
Merci.
I didn't need my father to prove I had terrible taste in men, Capitaine.
I do have one more question for you, if you don't mind.

Fields.MenuText: By all means.
If you must.
You should probably know that Morganas could attack at any moment.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll try to be quick.
Despite the progress in Zurich, you've heard that the bilateral talks between the Soviet Union and Finland have broken down, yes?
Yes.
What's your position on Soviet allegations that the Finns are collaborating with the Morganas? Do you think the Neutrality Fleet should assist in any Soviet attack on Finnish coastal fortifications?

Fields.MenuText: ... I was hoping for a question about favorite foods.
No. That's not the Fleet's mission.
I'm sure the League will examine the evidence and issue sensible guidelines.

Fields.DialogueText: It's my belief that the Fleet's mandate should be strictly limited to the destruction of Morgana infrastructure - along with information-gathering and search and rescue. At least for now.
So that's a "no comment?"
Well played, Capitaine.
That's "I prefer to avoid speculation about the future parameters of my ship's mission."
May I ask you a question? Not about your family relationships.
Bien sûr! I won't promise to answer.
The other night - was Orest suggesting that you were thinking of signing on with us?
Why? Do you have a desperate need for underemployed reporters?

Fields.MenuText: If I said yes?
I need smart, observant people. I tracked down some of your work.
Do you always answer a question with a question?

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
I should warn you - that happens a lot.
@BATTLE
Part of the job description.
Lugin, you're never going to convince me that the Marine Nationale just left a captured Soviet director by the side of the road.
You haven't seen me try yet.
But, no. This wasn't the Marine Nationale. This was a group of daring entrepreneurs who are doing their part for the West by injecting pure capitalism into Soviet-
Is it really so wrong to think we could give the poor thing a better home?

Fields.MenuText: So, basically, you're selling it to me like it's a stray puppy.
You do good work, sir.
And what's in it for you?

Fields.DialogueText: Do you ask McPhee why he does his job? Do you ask the crazy Japanese girl? Nyet! Only poor Lugin!
Da. Fine. I want to be on your good side when you realize I got us a bunch of defective refrigeration units.
I am just a simple man of simple talents, Kapitan.
Da. So cute.
... Also, it may be that the thing has been disassembled and its parts have been mixed in with several crates of French automotive supplies. But we have engineers!
Right. That's-
Fanny?
Bonjour, Capitaine! Bonjour, M`sieur Lugin! It's so good to see you again!
Weren't you off taking over the world?
Nonsense. Who has the energy for that?
I've just been throwing parties, darling. Good, clean fun!
"Good," "clean," and "fun?" I think you have to pick only two.
I'm glad they haven't civilized you, Orest.
Never! But, Kapitan, shall I-?

Fields.MenuText: Yeah, you can get back to work.
Fine. We'll take the director. Thank you.

Fields.DialogueText: And we'll talk later about the refrigeration units.
Da, da. You can imagine my delight!
So.
So. You look well!

Fields.MenuText: So do you.
Lies.
First things first. Are you here because there's trouble?

Fields.DialogueText: Bien sûr!
Oui. But affectionate ones.
Capitaine, there's always trouble. But you, my friend, are usually in the middle of it.
Right. Am I in the middle of it now?
*ALARM*
*ALARM*
I can't believe I set myself up for that.
Ah. It's like old times!
Capitaine - permission to come aboard?
Now?
Oui. I remember how to stay out of the way - and I imagine votre charmant docteur wouldn't say no to another pair of hands outside the sick bay.
... Very good, Madame Granville. Welcome aboard.
@BATTLE
*ahem*
And we'll talk later about the refrigeration units.
So somebody bribed somebody and ran off with it to France and then... what, the plan fell apart?
You make it sound so tawdry.
Do we know why she's here? She's not staying, is she?
I haven't had a chance to ask her yet. You can.
Nein. Nee. No. She and Marie-France are tearing each other to pieces, and I'm not going within a hundred feet of it.
That bad?
The line that stands out in my mind is, "Go on and leave, then. Live a meaningless life, and when you die no one will even notice you're gone." Only much louder, and with more cursing.
Right. Who said it to whom?
Oh, that was all Fanny. It-
*ALARM*
We'll talk later.
@BATTLE
Things haven't gotten any calmer since I was last here, have they?
No. I think I take that back. You're all more organized, I think. Bertie would have been proud.
He started a lot of it. The on-the-job training programs he and the lady of the ship put together - they're the bedrock of a lot of what we're doing now.
Would you hate me if I said part of me wishes he'd been just a little bit harder for you to do without?

Fields.MenuText: Of course not.
Trust me. It's been hard.
We can get sunk next battle if it makes you feel any better.

Fields.DialogueText: ... It *is* good to see you again, you know.
Oui. I suppose it has.
Ha! So considerate a host!

Fields.MenuText: Thank you.
You, too.
I know.

Fields.DialogueText: So, did you throw Marie-France overboard?
It was terrible of me to inflict her on you, I know.
Actually, I think I like her. Not least because she told me I didn't have to detain you and hand you over to local authorities for kidnapping.
Capitaine, I don't know if you've read any of her articles - but trust me when I say the French authorities would just thank me for removing a pest from their gardens. Un petit campagnol.
Will you join me for dinner? I'd like to see how everyone's doing.
Sure.
And you can tell me why you're dipping Sayako in oil....
They signed the big agreement in Zurich yesterday.
So I hear! Wine?
Did you get it from Lugin?
Non. Mon Dieu, non.

Fields.MenuText: Then yes, please.
Where's your taste for adventure?
Smart. But none for me, thanks.

Fields.DialogueText: I rank it below my taste for flavor.
Very good!
Ah, the burdens of command.
So... I'm surprised you're not in Zurich for the big event.
Really? You shouldn't be.
I cashed in every favor. I threatened everyone I could threaten. I lied, I cajoled, I seduced, I blackmailed.
"Now my charms are all o'erthrown. And what strength I have's mine own, which is most faint."

Fields.MenuText: Prospero? Really?
So you burned some bridges.

Fields.DialogueText: I would make an amazing Prospero, I'll have you know.
Oh, I burned every bridge.
I was never going to be popular, Capitaine. When the dust settled, they were never going to put me in the photographs with the statesmen and the admirals.
That's just the way it is. I was encouraged to be somewhere else when the documents were signed and the great galas thrown.
And I'm afraid that the people on this ship are as close as I have to friends and family anymore. Which is particularly sad in that Sayako's the only one I've known for more than a few weeks.

Fields.MenuText: Sometimes that's all you need.
I know the feeling.
Plus, if anyone comes after you for the attack on Avenol, you're hard to reach.

Fields.DialogueText: You think that was me?
Marie-France has a complicated theory about a man named Eufrasio Pansera, who was... what, a producer of a film or two you made in Italy?
Ah, oui. And a real criminal - if you can technically be a criminal when no one would ever charge you with committing a crime.
He liked the glamour of film, though, and he was willing to take chances.
So, I got him to attack the former Secretary General of the League of Nations? How enterprising of me!
No family and friends waiting for you back home?

Fields.MenuText: No, they're there. It just feels like another life.
No. Everything here is all I've got.
Actually, I was just trying to sound sympathetic. I have lots of people back home.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! I'm glad.
Is it enough?

Fields.MenuText: Yes.
Most days.
Best not to think about it.

Fields.DialogueText: Je comprends.
I'm not a crew member you need to inspire, Capitaine. It's okay.
Mm.
Capitaine, after Marie-France came to me with her theory, I talked with Pansera. He can provide a dozen witnesses who will swear he was in Milan the day Monsieur Avenol had his accident.
A cynic might say that that's not the same thing as saying he really was in Milan.
Who can afford to be cynical in a war, Capitaine?
Ah. I'm glad you didn't let Lugin choose-

Fields.MenuText: A "Captain of the Fleet." Whatever that ends up meaning.
Okay. I'm done pushing.
I just want to be sure you're not going to get yourself arrested, Fanny.

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
I'm not trying to inspire you. I'm saying we're all pretty comfortable calling ourselves your friends.
Ah.
Well, that's okay, then.
Damn. I have to-
Oui. So do I, I suppose.
@BATTLE
I know. Merci. It just-
Oh, it's not as though it's been unpleasant. You just-
Of course.
Would you rather have been something else, Capitaine? If you had it all to do over again?
If it's not rude to ask....
No. I'm as content as I can be, under the-
Captain? We've just had confirmation that your paperwork made it to Zurich and Geneva. You're officially the first captain of the Provisional Neutrality Fleet.
And... well, the impression I get is that the new League leadership hasn't really been settled and that we're more or less free to act on our discretion. Geneva will sign off on almost anything.

Fields.MenuText: Don't get your hopes up, Mr. Cassel. No vacation for us.
Damn. It's hard to coordinate if everyone else is hands off.
I can work with that.

Fields.DialogueText: ...  I don't want to overstep, but...
I don't want a vacation. There's too much to do.
Go ahead.
Is it time we move into the Baltic?
I mean, it sounds like the Morganas are getting more and more entrenched in Danzig Bay, and for all we know the Soviets are going to declare war on Finland. Having an active League presence there....
We're going to make another jump to Boston in the next few days - we're committed to being part of Constitution's escort, and hopefully we can help talk Congress into more support for the fleet.
After that, though... you're right, it's past time.
Ja. Much as I like sucking up to the Americans and taking tests, this feels like it could make more of a difference, you know?

Fields.MenuText: Care to rephrase that, Mr. Cassel?
You're about five seconds away from peeling potatoes for a month.
Oh, yeah. Your proficiency tests start tomorrow, don't they?

Fields.DialogueText: Sorry! Sorry! I know it's all important! It's just my way of-
It won't happen again.
I've literally had nightmares about forgetting how to turn on the radio.
That would be good.
Try not to do that in real life.
Thank you. I appreciate the-
*ALARM*
Here we go again.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I agree. It could do some good.
Believe me - nobody wants to be there right now more than I do. Nobody.

Fields.DialogueText: There's just one thing we have to take care of first.
And I'll tell you something! If you weren't so obsessed with libeling me-
It's not libel if it's true!
If you weren't so obsessed with libeling me, I was saying, you'd be looking at Morgana agents for the attack on Avenol.
Certainement! Just as soon as I've eliminated Père Noël as a suspect.
Hang on. Morgana agents?
Bonjour, Capitaine. Et, oui. Why not?
More context, please.
She's trying to distract me, Capitaine.
This is true. But it doesn't follow that there's nothing to it. You'll have seen reports of Morgana propaganda broadcasts, Capitaine?
We've stopped a few of them, actually.
Have you listened to them? They're gaining an audience.
You're kidding.
I haven't heard of any organized groups or political parties - but, non, she's not kidding. By the time I left Vannes, their message was becoming more sophisticated.
The governments of the world are blundering into another war and ignoring the needs of the common man.
The Morganas are here to tear it all down so the average fisherman and farmer can fight back for a little dignity. That kind of thing.
As they poison the air.
Ah, but if you're a German who doesn't like the Nazis but doesn't want to side with the perfidious French, this is a middle way. There's a kind of hopefulness in it.
But the Morganas never called for-
ITCHING POWDER? ITCHING POWDER?! DAMN YOU TO HELL, YOU MALIGNANT HARPY!
YOU STOLE MY NOTES!
YOUR NOTES WOULDN'T HAVE HELPED YOU! I HAVE THIS TEST IN THE- DAMMIT, SOMEONE SCRATCH MY BACK!
Pardon us, Kapitein. Ladies.

Fields.MenuText: It's possible the proficiency tests were a bad idea.
I should bring on a third doctor to beat them both.
Sorry. You were saying?

Fields.DialogueText: I... think you might miss Bertie's steadying influence more than I realized.
*ALARM*
I can't remember.
Ah, hell. Excuse me!
@BATTLE
You sure you don't want to come with us to the States?
Non. Merci, Capitaine, but my last great adventure to the far side of the Atlantic didn't end so well. Those are memories I....
Of course. I'm sorry.
Don't be. Just keep an eye on Bertie's daughter for me, will you? Marie, I mean - I know Sayako's taken care of.
She hasn't asked to join the crew. There's no indication at all she'll be coming along.
Non. She will.

Fields.MenuText: If you've ordered her to do it... you may have noticed that that doesn't work well.
Tell me you haven't packed her into another crate.
And you say this because...?

Fields.DialogueText: It works brilliantly! That girl  is too quick for her own good.
I won't pretend I haven't been tempted, but... non.
She's like him, Captaine. Not in most of the good ways, I grant you, but... she can see this ship is where the future will be made. She'll want to see it for herself.
But...
So. If you speak to Constitution, please tell her I received her letter, and give her my warmest regards!
She sent you a letter?
Bien sûr! Sayako told her about me, apparently.
Good things, I assume.
What other kind of thing *could* you say about me, Capitaine?
But she was asking me to write to the American Congress as much as anything else. She's a fighter, that one.
And that's something you really want for her, I take it.
I want her away from France. I think the war will come there sooner than we think, and I think the war will not be kind to brave girls who ask too many questions.

Fields.MenuText: Really? The sea war has calmed down, at least between human navies. I was hoping....
No. I don't suppose it will.
Right. What about you?

Fields.DialogueText: I survived show business, Capitaine. What's a little artillery fire?
That the Germans would leave Poland and the Sudetenland and the Allies would pretend it all never happened?
Well, it sounds silly when *you* say it.
I have that effect on a lot of happy thoughts, I'm afraid.
Keep working with her. We need her. And the League needs the Americans. We can't-
Were you really going to leave without saying goodbye?
Oh, chérie. I knew you'd never let me get away with it.
I... will leave you two to it. Until next time, Fanny.
Come back safe, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
You.
Moi?
Order her to do something, and she'll do it, because she assumes you'd only give her an order expecting her not to do it.
It's a Russian doll of stubbornness and poor choices.
What I don't understand is how you got the invitation in the first place.
Well, I wrote to her. She writes to everyone else - I thought she might like receiving some mail.
And, of course, France played a part in the American Revolution. I may have mentioned that.

Fields.MenuText: I don't think Constitution needs reminders about eighteenth-century history from any of us.
Well played.
You know, Fanny said you'd be coming along.

Fields.DialogueText: Ugh.
Merci!
I think she enjoys the chance to reminisce. And there's so much we can learn!
I have to warn you - again - the plan is to be there for three or four days and then to attempt a leap straight to the Baltic Sea.
It's not going to be the same as being our guest in the Bay of Biscay. As a civilian passenger, your movements are almost guaranteed to be more restricted than they've been so far.
Of course. And, Capitaine, I want to be productive while I'm here. I can help clean or cook or... anything you think I'm qualified to do.
*ALARM*
Hide.
Oui.
@BATTLE
I still can't wrap my head around how quiet Boston is.
Where's Haarlem relative to here?
"Harlem," man. Just "Harlem."
You Americans just like to complicate everything, don't you?
You're the ones who added the extra "a."
It's a couple of hundred miles further down the coast, Mr. Cassel.
Right. Were you ever here before? Boston?
No. Not really my patch.
Ohayo, guys! Kanchou, is this a good time to make a request?
Seaman Kirishima-
Don't you think it should be "Seaperson" now, though?
What do you need?
I was hoping I could visit Constitution again. I got some paint for her globe from Brest, and-
Sayako, I don't think you want to-
I'd want to clear the visit with Constitution and her captain, but I don't think there'd be any problem. You could cross over with Marie-France.
Oh.
Ja.
Never mind, Kanchou. Maybe next time!
You don't have to bow to me, Sea- Oh. She's already gone.
... She's fighting with Marie-France, I take it?
Marie-France doesn't even know who she is. That's why she's been keeping her head down for the last few days - she's hoping they never have to meet.

Fields.MenuText: Right. I'm running a kindergarten.
Maybe that's for the best.
Okay. That's all I needed to know.

Fields.DialogueText: She's just... not a fan of unnecessary conflict.
She definitely thinks so. She can still hardly talk about Bertie - Commander Granville - without crying, and Marie-France strikes her as someone who...
Comes out swinging?
Ja. That.
Speaking of unnecessary conflict - the doctors are taking their proficiency tests today, right?
Seemed like a good idea to schedule them while we were in the Boston safety zone.
Because every day has to have some potential calamity?
You really *have* learned from your time in the radio room.
Okay, people. This is a hunting mission.
We're assuming that Constitution is more vulnerable when in transit, so I want us between her and any Morgana off the New England coast.
Especially given the history of Vanity-class battleships in the area.
We sweep, we clear the way, and Constitution and the US Navy escort group follow. We-
*ALARM*
Well, that was easy.
Don't jinx it, Lieutenant.
@BATTLE
Sir? I'm in radio contact with Constitution.
All's well, I hope.
Ja. But it's... apparently Asphyxiation made a run on the escort fleet from the east while we were dealing with the mess to the south.
Constitution was apparently grazed by a torpedo - a dud, I mean. Then they think Asphyxiation had a torpedo launch malfunction. Blew herself up.

Fields.MenuText: You're kidding.
Ha! Tell me somebody got it on film.
Was that Constitution defending herself, or just pure luck?

Fields.DialogueText: Divine intervention, maybe.
They didn't say, sir.
Sorry. Sounds like it happened pretty fast.
It's what they told me, sir.
They're making for the Port of Philadelphia to make sure that Constitution's still fit to travel.
Very good, Mr. Cassel. Let them know we'll keep watch.
Well, obviously, you and Lugin should go check it out.
Ha! Yeah, send me and the Russian guy to inspect and requisition American naval ordnance.
Worried it's not worth the trouble?
I'm more worried about getting shot, thank you.
Ah, then I can come with you. German Jews are famously welcome wherever we go!

Fields.MenuText: Don't worry. Next American shopping run, we'll just send Sayako.
I don't care who we send, but send somebody. If we can get a 14-inch gun, I want it.

Fields.DialogueText: And I will make it known that if anyone on shore gives any of my crew any crap, I'm not above-
Why didn't we think of that?
Because giving Sayako a blank check with the Captain's signature is-
*static*did flip the switch! This is why I prefer correspondence.
Our mystery signal, I assume.
Hallo? Who is this?
... I think it's Constitution, Mr. Cassel.
Oh. Oh!
And may I assume I'm speaking to the famous Captain?
We'll give you some privacy, Captain.
Very good, Lieutenant.
One moment. Is that Lieutenant McPhee?
Ah... yes, ma'am.
I did receive your letter, Lieutenant. I've been trying to compose a reply. And failing. Obviously.
For now, I just want you to know that I will do better. I will try harder.
This nation was always a gamble that it was possible to do things better than they had been done, had we but space to try.
If you keep trying, I'll keep trying. You have my word on that.
... I'll hold you to that, ma'am. But for now I'm going to turn you over to the Captain.
Thank you, though.
It *will* come.
*sigh*
I don't know if you've discovered this yet, Captain - but once people start thinking of you as a symbol as much as a person, you find so many more opportunities to put your foot firmly in your mouth.

Fields.MenuText: I never needed to be famous to do that.
If it makes you feel any better, I think of you as a ship, not a symbol.
Sounded to me like you were doing all right.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, you are the first person who's had the courtesy to say that to me since I woke up. I see why all the new girls are so fond of you.
Not that it was certain, nor that it would be easy, but that it was within our reach.
Oh, it doesn't matter. One thing at a time.
That's not the impression I have of you.
Now, I should tell you, I'm sensing something coming our way.
Sin, I think. I should be able to discourage her and her friends from attacking Pennsylvania, but I think it would still be a good idea to sink them before they bother anyone else.
I've told your Belle where to look, if that helps.
Thank you. I think.
Don't worry. The rain should keep their bombers out of play.
Sure.
Oh, and please thank Sayako for the paint! It was just what the globe needed!
Right. I'll-
Don't worry - I'll send her a proper thank-you letter when this is all done. But you should probably get going now.
I know I'm being rude, and I'm sorry about it - but thank you. I don't think you'll ever know the difference you're making.
Marie, can you*static*
... Huh.
@BATTLE
Provenance isn't entirely American. The Brits salvaged it from somewhere and sent it back to be refurbished - but it's supposed to be earmarked for us.
There's a lot of wiggle room in that "supposed to be," Captain.
Mr. Lugin?
I didn't do it unless you have proof I did it, in which case it was for a good cause.

Fields.MenuText: Don't worry. If you've done anything wrong I haven't heard about it yet.
Unless it wasn't for a good cause, in which case...
Stop grinning at me and listen for a second.

Fields.DialogueText: I will do my best.
I'm sure it will at least have been impressive.
Music to my ears, Kapitan.
So, if I'm not due for a nap in the brig, what can I do for you? A carton of cigarettes at below market prices?
We just had word. A few hours ago, the Soviet Union announced that Finnish forces "materially assisted" a Morgana attack on the Gulf of Finland.
A suburb called Sestroretsk was apparently leveled. Moscow's howling for blood, and the Zurich Agreement basically ensures the League can't do anything but conduct an independent investigation.
Very sad. Not sad enough for a discount on the carton of cigarettes, but-
I think we can take it as a given that the Finns wouldn't be stupid enough to provoke the Soviet Union now.
History is made up of people doing stupid things at bad times. But, say you're right.
I'm looking for an opinion from a Moscow man. Do you think there would be any point to leaving the escort mission and jumping to the Baltic? Is there any chance we can fix this?
... You really thought you had it all figured out, didn't you?
Pardon me?
Zurich. Then being able to be everywhere at once. You were starting to relax.

Fields.MenuText: You're avoiding the question.
No. I wish I'd been able to, but... no.
I didn't ask to be psychoanalyzed.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, well. Your answer?
Nyet. Unless you and Constitution can jump the ship to Stalin's office, there is nothing we can do.
We should probably just hope that the Finns surrender immediately so that the Military Maritime Fleet doesn't have too many distractions.
And so that we don't get too many orders to root out "Morgana collaborators" up north.
Yeah. That's what I figured.
A few dozen cigarettes might help improve your-
*ALARM*
Maybe some other time.
@BATTLE
Still got it.
Ideally, you wouldn't. More honest that way.
Is it just me, or are they coming in faster than usual today?
It's not just you. They're running out of chances to stop Constitution from reaching the Potomac.
We're assuming she'll be as safe there as she was in Boston, of course.
Besides, I hear FDR's her biggest fan - I think she can count on significant protection, whether she wants it or not.
You never said what was in that letter she sent you. I know it's none of my business, but-
No, it's fine. It was about 80% inspirational - beautiful, actually - and 20% weird guesswork about what I was taught in church growing up.

Fields.MenuText: Hoping, not assuming, and definitely not counting on.
Well, the whole point of this exercise is that her presence might protect Washington.
Why does everyone around here insist on healthy skepticism?

Fields.DialogueText: Sorry.
No, it's a fair point. But she wants to do it and the U.S. Navy wants her to do it, so... here we are.
Huh.
Don't get me wrong, I'm definitely getting it framed. I may just fold it creatively, or-
*ALARM*
Right. In firing range in...
@BATTLE
Well, Lieutenant, you called it - they weren't playing that time.
Somebody get eyes on Constitution! Make sure nothing got past us!
And if anybody spots the Doctor coming to give me a checkup, tell him I'm sure the crew needs him more!
Lieutenant, I need you to get me-
The Doctor's not coming, Kanchou! He's hurt!
Oh, hell.
Seaman - Sayako - how bad is it?
I don't know! He was awake, but there was metal sticking out of his side! He was on the deck with someone who couldn't be moved, and-
Relax. Just relax. He's in good hands with Dr. van Geffen.
*sniff* He's gonna be so mad if she saves his life.
And that's something to look forward to. Listen, you have duties to attend to, so-
*BOOM*
Dammit, was that us?!
... Constitution.
Here's what we know. The bomber somehow got aboard Constitution at Philadelphia.
He seems to have been a short-range radio enthusiast. Accidentally made contact with Morganas, and became convinced-
Wait. He was just some idiot?
He became convinced that his kids were going to be drafted to fight a naval war for the Soviet Union unless he did something to stop Constitution.
We don't know where the explosives came from. He left a note, but the people investigating aren't sharing any details.
Let the Captain speak, Mr. Cassel.
You all know that Mademoiselle Savary was evacuated with the last-
Yeoman Savary.
I'm sorry. You don't just get to-
She made me a yeoman. At the end. I had been helping her with her letters, and she... when she was going down, she asked me if I wanted to serve, and I said yes.
... Right. We'll discuss this later.
But, for now, do you have anything to add?
Je ne sais pas. I... um... I was there when she... when she faded out. She lasted long enough to give orders about evacuating the crew. And saving her trailboards. And-
The trailboards? You're sure?
Oui. If there's ever another ship named "Constitution," she thought... she thought the new Belle might like-
Right. I understand.
And she wrote one last... exhortation to the U.S. Congress. A short one.
And she said, at the end, that she returned to her maker unafraid.
Is that literally true? Are they taking what they can salvage to whatever port built her in the first place?

Fields.MenuText: Let's not get into Belle metaphysics now, Mr. Cassel.
I have no idea.
Quiet down!

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, with respect, we have a more pressing problem.
Constitution's been coordinating a lot of our travels here. Without her help, can we do these jumps safely anymore?
I don't see that we have any choice but to-
*ALARM*
I'll tell you all - I'm even more ready to sink these things than usual right now.
As long as you remember that one of our doctors is on bed rest. Um... sir.
That just adds to my bad mood, Mr. Cassel.
@BATTLE
We can't rule out the possibility that there was more than one individual involved.
Metaphysics, hell. This is an ally.
Captain, if there's a chance in hell-
Hello, Kanchou! You look-
Not the time for small talk, Kirishima. Not at all the time.
For all the fun you've had at Cassel's expense, he never needed to be told not to go AWOL to harass the US Coast Guard for souvenirs from-
Gomen!
Save the apologies until I'm done. Those people you intruded upon have impossible jobs to do and very little time to do them, and for you to disrupt that and make a scene just to-
Gomen'nasai!
And that letter you had from "Constitution" saying she wanted you to have your trophy? I assume that was forged?
Hai. Um... samples of her handwriting aren't all that hard to come by.

Fields.MenuText: I know you have an attachment to that damn globe, but that doesn't excuse the commission of actual crimes!
Give me one good reason not to kick you off this ship. And that's not a joke.
... So tell me what I'm missing.

Fields.DialogueText: Kanchou, it's not about having an attachment!
I mean, I do, but....
They took all of Constitution's stuff off the ship when she was sinking so it could go into a museum somewhere. You know they did!
But the globe... I mean, when I first visited her, maybe it was just for show, but she marked the globe to show where we were going to jump to. Remember?
And, I thought, maybe it's a way she can keep on helping us. I think she would have wanted to.

Fields.MenuText: That's magical thinking. Even with Belles, you know it's a stretch.
Oh. Okay, that's an interesting thought.
Yeah, you're still going to the brig.

Fields.DialogueText: Hai... but what if it works?
Thank you.
Don't look so smug.
*sigh*
Just take the globe to the bridge and try it when we try to jump, Kanchou. Have our Kami look at it!
Punish me however you want, but I'm sure this is at least worth trying.
... In addition to your regular duties, you're going to provide assistance to the Doctor while he recovers.
And that includes listening to him gripe about how his test scores were better than those of the woman who stitched him up and is now running sick bay.
Ugh.
And, Kirishima...

Fields.MenuText: It *was* a clever idea.
Next time, ask the Lieutenant or me first.
You are on the thinnest possible ice right now. Don't screw up.

Fields.DialogueText: Hai!
I'm sorry, Kanchou.
*grins*

Fields.MenuText: I know.
No, you're not.

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
I guess you got back just in time.
@BATTLE
I thought you'd never ask.
Everything's about ready, Captain.
You don't look happy about it, Lieutenant.
I don't know. I feel like we should be having a service for her, or something. For her and for what we lost.
I mean, I know how important it is that we throw ourselves into another dimension with no guarantee we'll ever get back, but....
It *is* important. You heard the USSR and Finland are at war?
Augie told me.
We just had a month when we could pretend the war in Europe wasn't really real. I think that's over.
And we both know the Morganas aren't getting weaker. We hoped they would exhaust their resources without all the infrastructure humanity takes for granted, but... no.
We need to be able to be everywhere, Lieutenant. We need it now.
I know.
... I would've liked to have known her better, you know?

Fields.MenuText: Yeah. Me, too.
You know what she stood for. Maybe that's enough.
You know there'll be another USS Constitution. Maybe we'll get a second chance.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't bother waiting for the whites of their eyes!
@BATTLE
Yeah.
So, you're really gonna try this thing with the globe, huh? How's that going to work?
Well, we clear the bridge - apart from the lady of the ship and myself - and I look at the globe, and I point to where we want to go. And then we try to go there.
... You really have no idea, do you?
I've been flying without a net since the day this started, Lieutenant.
Well, sir... respectfully, I'd very much appreciate it if you didn't kill us all with this crazy idea.

Fields.MenuText: Noted.
I find your lack of faith disturbing.
I'll do my best.

Fields.DialogueText: Ready? Shall I see myself out?
See you on the other side, Lieutenant.
